availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: This manuscript contains a draft version of the poem "Broadway". A note appearing at the top of the page states "Sent Herald March 3â€”sent again April 9 '88" indicating that this manuscript was likely composed and/or edited around the time of its first publication in the New York Herald, April 10, 1888.

body.note:
sent to Herald March 3 — sent again April 9
'88

lg.l:
What endlesshurrying human tides, or day or glit–
teringglittering
night!

l.del: ThereWithin that channels nor too narrow nor too wide.

lg.l: What passions, evils, ‸winnings, losses, ardors, swim thy waters!

What varied bliss and sorrow stem thee! — what
looks!

(The ‸What such,What curious questioning glances — the glowsglints
of love,
Leer, envy, scorn, disdaincontempt,, hope, aspiration!!)

Thou portal — thou arena — thou of the
endless,married long–drawn lines and groups.

(could but thy flagstones, porches, curbs, ‸façades, tell their interminable
tales;

Thy windows rich, and huge hotels — thy
sidewalks wide,

With sliding, mincing, skipping, shuffling
myriadendlessfeet.
Thou, ‸visor'd like the ‸parti⹀color'd world itself — like ‸parti⹀color'd‸infinite teeming masking life,
AThou variedvisor'd, vast, untellableunspeakable show and lesson!

body.note:
could but thy flagstones curls, façades
their story, tell tales their tales interminable
